questions.question_text: A network administrator is designing a new network for a company that has frequent power spikes. The company wants to ensure that employees can keep working and the server will remain operational. Which of the following is the best solution for the administrator to recommend?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Answer is D. UPS

Selected Answer: D
D. Uninterruptible power supply (UPS)

To protect against power spikes and ensure continuity of operations during power outages, a UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply) is the best solution. A UPS provides a temporary power source during electrical failures, allowing systems to shut down gracefully or continue operating for a short duration until power is restored or a generator takes over.

While a generator (option A) is a solution for longer-term power outages, a UPS is typically used for short-term disruptions and provides immediate protection against power spikes and brief outages.

Therefore, the best recommendation for the network administrator is D. Uninterruptible power supply (UPS).

Selected Answer: D
Uninterruptible Power Supplies (UPS) typically have "line conditioning" capabilities that can alleviate troublesome surges (spikes) and drops in voltage.

questions.question_text: Which of the following OSI model layers are responsible for handling packets from the sources to the destination and checking for errors? (Choose two.)

comments.content: ngl very chatgpt vibes and idk how i feel about that

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C. Data link
D. Network

Layers responsible for handling packets from source to destination and checking for errors in the OSI model are:

C. Data link: This layer is responsible for framing packets, error detection, and handling the access to the physical network medium. It includes the logical link control (LLC) sublayer and the media access control (MAC) sublayer.

D. Network: This layer is responsible for routing packets between different networks, logical addressing, and providing services such as fragmentation and error handling. It includes IP (Internet Protocol) in the case of the TCP/IP protocol suite.

Therefore, the correct answers are C. Data link and D. Network.

Selected Answer: CD
Isn't it ment to be data link and transport layer ?
data link layer picks up CRC errors and transport layer protcol TCP would pick up incorrect orders of packets, missing packets + re-request the packet...?

Selected Answer: CD
The Network layer handles packets and routes them as necessary. The Data Link layer is responsible for error control/detection.
Maybe not, but I'm kind of a fan of including the session layer in this.

questions.question_text: Which of the following fiber connector types is the most likely to be used on a network interface card?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
LC - widely used due to its small size and ease of use
SC - used in Gigabit Ethernet networks, datacom, and telecom applications
ST - used in multimode datacom (but was replaced by SC and LC)
MPO - used in high-speed data center applications

Selected Answer: A
A. LC

The LC (Lucent Connector) is the most likely fiber connector type to be used on a network interface card (NIC). LC connectors are small, have a high density, and are commonly used in data center and enterprise environments. They are well-suited for connections on NICs and switches due to their compact size and ease of use.

Therefore, the correct answer is A. LC.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the most cost-effective way for a network administrator to establish a persistent, secure connection between two facilities?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Site-to-site VPN

A site-to-site VPN (Virtual Private Network) is the most cost-effective way for a network administrator to establish a persistent, secure connection between two facilities. It allows secure communication over the internet by encrypting the data transmitted between the two locations. Site-to-site VPNs are a practical and economical solution for connecting geographically dispersed sites over the public internet while maintaining a high level of security.

Selected Answer: C
Ah I would say “Badge Reader” as well…initially I said “smart deadbolt” like an idiot like some of you. But when you think about it IT personnel, facilities personnel, building personnel, ISP or vendors sometimes need access to the “IDF” aka Intermediate Distribution Frame”…so allowing people to access the IDF is crucial therefore having a “Badge Reader” there for access does two things…locks/unlocks doors and most importantly records who is badging in and out of the IDF…that there is why a Smart Deadbolt is irrelevant and useless…if you said Smart Deadbolt that means you never worked in an IT setting…or an ideal setting.

Selected Answer: D
Smart deadbolt should be the answer since we're talking about an IDF
Smart deadbolt should be the answer since we're talking about an IDF
what are these ChatGPT answers bro T_T.

Selected Answer: C
C. RFID badge readers

An Intermediate Distribution Frame (IDF) in a secure facility typically houses networking equipment and connections. In this context, security measures are likely to involve access control to the networking infrastructure. RFID (Radio-Frequency Identification) badge readers are commonly used for secure access control in facilities. These readers can authenticate individuals based on RFID badges or cards, providing a secure means of access to network equipment.

While options A (Full-size body scanners) and B (Iris scanner) are more associated with physical security measures for access to the facility, option D (Smart deadbolt) is related to securing physical doors and may not be directly tied to securing the network infrastructure in the IDF.

Therefore, the most relevant security measure for an IDF installation in a secure facility is likely to be C. RFID badge readers.
